text.p: Yemen slashed its budget deficit between January and September thanks to economic reforms agreed with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), a Central Bank official said on Tuesday.
The official, who requested anonymity, said the deficit in the first nine months stood at 7.08 billion rial ($70 million), compared with 21.85 billion rial during the same period in 1995.
The 181.41 billion rial budget for 1996, endorsed by parliament during a stormy session in March, had a projected deficit of 25.53 billion rials.

"The economic reforms programme and the Central Bank's activation of monetary policy tools helped reduce the deficit," said the official. "It was covered by non-inflationary sources through issuing treasury bills".
The net bill value between January and September stood at 8.01 billion rials, he added.

In January, impoverished Yemen, a recent member of the elite club of Arab oil exporters, started implementing the second phase of wide-ranging reforms agreed upon by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Foreign exchange reserves are currently standing at $900 million, up on $450 million in May.
Yemen first introduced treasury bills in December.
A Central Bank official said last week Sanaa plans to issue treasury bills weekly, instead of monthly, to "benefit the government in financing emergencies in government spending".
It currently issues 91- and 182-day bills every month.
